A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Polynomial need to be defined for a definition of a/an Intersection of Ideals to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of an Intersection of Ideals involves the intersection of two ideals within a ring, defined as the set of elements that belong to both ideals. This concept is purely based on the properties and elements of ideals within a ring, and does not inherently require the elements to be polynomials or any specific type of element beyond being members of the ring.

On the other hand, the concept of a Polynomial involves a formal sum of terms with coefficients in a field or ring, expressed in powers of a variable. This concept is specific to the structure and properties of polynomials as algebraic expressions.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of an Intersection of Ideals do not depend on the concept of a Polynomial. The Intersection of Ideals can be defined and understood entirely within the context of ring theory without any reference to the nature of the elements (whether they are polynomials or not) as long as they belong to the ring.
